J.B. Writes:

> Also, Agitator can help retrofit tests to legacy code, howe=
ver it 
> /doesn't/ help you identify the specific design problems in that =
code, 
> nor does it motivate you to improve the design. This might or migh=
t not 
> concern your team at this time.

This is Alberto jumping in again =
to set the record straight on
Agitator ...

Hi Joe, you might not remember =
me but we exchanged emails a couple of
years ago, and I am a big fan of you=
rs for all the work you have done
to educate people about JUnit through you=
r book and online presence.

Anyway ... your description of using Agitator =
to complement TDD is
spot-on (for people who do TDD) - thank you for jumpin=
g in and helping
in setting the record straight.  But you also state (I par=
aphrase):
"Agitator does not help you identify design problems or motivate =
you
to improve the design".  We have actually found, somewhat
serendipitous=
ly, that Agitator does indeed help you in identifying
design problems and e=
ven provides you compelling motivations to
address them (e.g. well designed=
 code Agitates better).

A simple example, of Agitator helping you improve =
your design is
blogged on developertesting.com:

http://www.developertestin=
g.com/archives/month200402/20040226-TestDrivenDevelopmentAndAgitatorDrivenR=
efactoring.html

Again, this does not mean that Agitator replaces TDD, but =
it can
complement TDD efforts (our own Dashboard product was developed
prac=
ticing TDD, pair-programming, etc., AND Agitator of course).

Alberto





=
